<h2 align="center">How to set up Thunderbird to Read @cam Email

If you'd rather not use Webmail to check your Cambridge email, you could use Mozilla Thunderbird, a free email and news client. This document tells you how to set up Thunderbird to check your @cam account.

Please note that with these settings, you will be required to type in your password both when Thunderbird is started and when you send your first message of the session. Please don't choose to save your email password unless you're sure that you are the only one who will be accessing the computer on which you have set up your email. You are responsible if anyone gets into your email account and sends messages which breaks the rules or guidelines set forth by the IT Syndicate or the policies of JANET, the University's ISP. If you've never read these documents, I would recommend reading them before you begin.
• Download Thunderbird from the Mozilla web site
• Start to install Thunderbird by double-clicking the setup icon. Click Next on the window that comes up.
• Read and Accept the terms of the license agreement and click next.
• Leave the default 'Standard' option ticked on the 'Setup Type' screen. Click next.
• When it's finished it will display a window saying so. Leave the 'Launch Mozilla Thunderbird' item ticked and click 'Finish'.
• When Thunderbird starts up, it should ask you if you want to set up a new Email, News or RSS Feed. Email should be selected by default, but if not, select it and click the 'Next' button.
• Type your name into the first field - this is how your name will show up when someone receives mail from you. Type your full email address into the second field (something@cam.ac.uk). Click 'Next'
• Choose 'IMAP' for 'Type of Server' and type: imap.hermes.cam.ac.uk into the 'Incoming Server Name' field. For the SMTP/Outgoing server, type: smtp.hermes.cam.ac.uk and click next.
• Make sure your user ID is in both the 'Incoming Username' and 'Outgoing Username' fields and click next.

• You can either leave 'Account Name' as the default (usually your email address) or type in something like 'Cambridge' or 'Cambridge email' and click next. Remember what you called your account, as it will be important in the following instructions (I will use 'Cambridge' as the account name in the instructions, but just substitute whatever you called yours)

• You should be asked for your password. Go ahead and type it in. This will load up your email, which may take a while. Already being logged in will also be helpful when doing the next part of the setup.

• There are a few things you need to tweak to make Thunderbird run properly. In the Tools menu, choose 'Account Settings'. Under 'Cambridge' (or whatever you called your account) on the left-hand side, there should be a 'Server Settings' section. Select this.

• On the right, you should see a section called 'Security Settings'. Under this, is an option that says, 'Use Secure connection'. Make sure SSL has a dot in the circle and that 'Use Secure Authentication' is not ticked.

There are many reasons I don't recommend this option for use at the Faculty or in your college, but the simplest is that, generally, you're always connected.

Select this and click the 'Edit' button on the right. In the window that comes up, change the port from '25' to '587'. Make sure that the 'Use name and password' box is ticked, that your username is correct, and that the dot is in the circle in front of 'TLS'.
• Click the OK button at the bottom-right of the 'Account Settings' window.
• Go back to the Tools Menu and select 'Options'
• Under the 'General' tab, tick 'Mail' in the default settings section. This will make Thunderbird your default mail client.

• In the 'Display' section (just click 'Display' at the top of the 'Options' window), _un_tick the box that says, 'Display emoticons as graphics'. Unless you want to see them as graphics, of course... generally I just find them annoying, though.
• In the 'composition' tab, in the 'Forward Messages' section, select 'inline' from the drop down menu. Also, make sure that 'Confirm when using keyboard shortcut to send message' is ticked.
• In the 'Privacy' tab, make sure that 'Block loading of remote images in mail messages' and 'Block Javascript in Mail Messages' are ticked.
• Click OK on the bottom right of the option window.
